Package edu.ncsu.csc316.dsa.tree

Interface Tree<E>

  • Type Parameters:
    E - the type of elements stored in the tree
    All Known Subinterfaces:
    BinaryTree<E>
    All Known Implementing Classes:
    AbstractBinaryTree, AbstractTree, LinkedBinaryTree
    public interface Tree<E>
    The Tree abstract data type represents a hierarchical collection of elements, where each. The Tree ADT does not restrict the number of children that each node may have. All Trees must be Iterable to allow clients to iterate using for-each loops. The Tree interface is based on the implementation developed for use with the textbook: Data Structures and Algorithms in Java, Sixth Edition Michael T. Goodrich, Roberto Tamassia, and Michael H. Goldwasser John Wiley and Sons, 2014
    Author:
    Dr. King

    • Method Summary

      All Methods Instance Methods Abstract Methods 
      Modifier and Type Method Description
      Position<E> addRoot​(E element)
      Returns a reference to the new root position of the tree that is created to store the given element
      java.lang.Iterable<Position<E>> children​(Position<E> p)
      Returns an Iterable collection of positions that represent children of the given position
      boolean isEmpty()
      Returns true if the tree contains no elements, otherwise return false
      boolean isInternal​(Position<E> p)
      Returns true if the provided position has at least 1 child
      boolean isLeaf​(Position<E> p)
      Returns true if the provided position has no children
      boolean isRoot​(Position<E> p)
      Returns true if the provided position is the root of the tree
      java.lang.Iterable<Position<E>> levelOrder()
      Returns an Iterable collection of positions that represent the levelorder traversal of positions within the tree
      int numChildren​(Position<E> p)
      Returns the number of children of the provided position
      Position<E> parent​(Position<E> p)
      Returns a reference to the parent of the provided position, p
      java.lang.Iterable<Position<E>> postOrder()
      Returns an Iterable collection of positions that represent the postorder traversal of positions within the tree
      java.lang.Iterable<Position<E>> preOrder()
      Returns an Iterable collection of positions that represent the preorder traversal of positions within the tree
      E remove​(Position<E> p)
      Removes the provided position from the tree.
      Position<E> root()
      Returns a reference to the root position of the tree
      E set​(Position<E> p, E element)
      Updates the given position to have the provided element.
      int size()
      Return the number of elements stored in the tree

        Position<E> addRoot​(E element)
        Returns a reference to the new root position of the tree that is created to store the given element
        Parameters:
        element - the element to add to the tree
        Returns:
        the root position that is created to store the element
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if the tree already has an existing root position

        Throws:

      • remove

        E remove​(Position<E> p)
        Removes the provided position from the tree. Returns the element that was stored in the position that is removed.
        Parameters:
        p - the position for which to remove from the tree
        Returns:
        the element that was stored in the position that is removed
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if the position, p, does not represent a valid tree position
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if removal of the position is not allowed

      • set

        E set​(Position<E> p,
      E element)
        Updates the given position to have the provided element.
        Parameters:
        p - the position for which to update the element stored at that position
        element - the new element that should replace the existing element in the provided position
        Returns:
        the original element that was replaced by the new element at the provided position
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if the position, p, does not represent a valid tree position
